key_insight: WorldCanvas fuses text, explicit motion trajectories (with timing and visibility) and reference images to produce richly controllable, visually grounded event simulations—bridging semantic intent and concrete appearance in generated scenes.
problem_solved: Current text-only or trajectory-only image-to-video methods lack both precise semantic control and visual grounding of object identity, making it hard to specify what happens, when it happens, and how specific objects should look during an event.
method: Multimodal conditioning: combine natural language for high-level intent, trajectories for motion/timing/visibility, and reference images for appearance grounding.
Fusion and generation pipeline: encode and align modalities (semantic + spatial-temporal + visual) into a unified representation, then decode into coherent event sequences.
Promptable interface: user-specified prompts (text + trajectories + reference images) enable controllable variations and consistent object identity across time.
impact: Enables practitioners to generate and edit temporally coherent, identity-preserving event simulations with fine-grained control—useful for content creation, virtual environments, and data-driven simulation for downstream tasks.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: inputs (text, trajectory timeline, reference image) → multimodal fusion → generated video frames.
Trajectory timeline overlay: timeline view showing motion paths, timing markers, and visibility/on-off intervals for objects.
Before/after gallery: variations produced by changing one modality (e.g., different reference image or altered trajectory) to show controllability.
Icon set: simple icons for Language, Motion/Trajectory, and Reference Image to communicate modality roles at a glance.
paper_title: The World is Your Canvas: Painting Promptable Events with Reference Images, Trajectories, and Text
paper_authors: Hanlin Wang, Hao Ouyang, Qiuyu Wang, Yue Yu, Yihao Meng
